XR TREES HOIMA DEMANDS THE G7 SAVE THE BUGOMA FOREST

üé§ Pass The Mic: G7 Global Rebellion üé§ 

XR Trees Hoima joins the global action to amplify our voices about the Save Bugoma Forest campaign. 5 sq miles of land part of Bugoma tropical forest were given away to Hoima Sugar for sugar cane growing. Activists together with other environmental conservation organisations sued Hoima Sugar and National Environmental Management Authority, NEMA, in the courts of law for issuing a licence to Hoima Sugar which the activists termed as illegal and unlawful action. The activists lost the case to Hoima Sugar, meaning they will go ahead to clear cut the forest and plant sugar cane which still activists are against it.

‚ÄúWe are calling upon the G7 countries to stop supporting the so called investors of Hoima Sugar in terms of loans and put a total ban of their products to be consumed in their countries.

We are working to support community tree planting by giving them quality indigenous tree seedlings for planting in their degraded farm lands as well as raising awareness of the dangers associated with cutting the forest which include among others, wildlife displacement hence conflicts between communities and wildlife, climate change, desertification, etc.‚Äù 
- XR Trees Hoima, Uganda
xr_uganda

Reposted from extinctionrebellion G7 - HONOUR YOUR ENVIRONMENTAL DEBTS

We, in the Global South, call on the G7 to take ownership of its immense responsibility for the climate crisis. We are losing our seasonal weather patterns. We are losing our homes and livelihoods to floods, fires, sea-level rise and extreme weather. We did not cause this, G7, you did. Honour the climate debt you owe us. 

The poorest 50% of humanity only accounted for 7% of the cumulative emissions between 1990 and 2015. While 10% of the richest accounted for 52%.

We call on the G7 to take ownership of its immense responsibility for environmental destruction. You let your companies pollute our lands with mining, fracking, forest and ecosystem destruction of all kinds. You even dump your waste in our lands. Our water is undrinkable, our soil unproductive, our air filthy. Honour the debt you owe us for this immense environmental destruction.

Post Credit: cop26_extinctionrebellion

Army relief workers in aluminium dinghies handed out rice and other food to residents in submerged parts of the Sri Lankan capital as the death toll from monsoon floods across the country rose to 17 yesterday. The monsoon hits the South Asian country twice a year, bringing vital rain for irrigation and hydro-power generation, but it can be deadly and destructive.

This week we are going to explore the Rancocas Creek that flows through Burlington County. From our photo collection we have some images of a flood of Mason‚Äôs Creek around 1940. Mason‚Äôs Creek is a tributary of the Rancocas. The flood was so severe that it damaged the bridge near Creek Road and Marne Highway. #Rancocas #Creeks #Floods #BurlingtonCounty

For many people in the world the climate has already changed
lens_pacific Vlad Sokhin‚Äôs ambitious Warm Waters project visits some of the world‚Äôs most remote communities from Utqiagvik at the northernmost tip of the USA, to the southernmost islands in the Pacific, Niue and New Zealand‚Äôs Tokelau.  His aim to show the consequences of the climate emergency in the Artic and the South Pacific. On first sight these communities could not be more different yet they are united by their first hand experience of the impact of our changing climate.  They are the ‚Äòcanaries in the coal mine‚Äô of global warming. 
 
Photo 1: Peia Kararaua, 16, swims in the flooded area of Aberao village. Kiribati is one of the countries most affected by sea level rise. During high tides many villages become inundated making large parts of them uninhabitable. Aberao, South Tarawa, Kiribati
 
Photo 2: Amaia, 11, an Inupiat girl, standing on sea ice floating in the Arctic Ocean off Utqiagvik.  Average temperature in Utqiagvik has risen nearly 3 degrees in the last 50 years.  Alaska, USA
 
Photo 3: A group of teenagers riding bicycles on the beach next to a derelict apartment block in the so-called 2nd Base, an area of Oktyabrskiy that is heavily affected by coastal erosion. Locals and climate experts believe global warming is responsible, as the mild weather melts the sea ice which once protected the shores of Oktyabrskiy from strong autumn and winter storms. Oktiyabrsky, Kamchatka Krai, Russia 
 
Photo 4: Frank, 13, standing on a seawall that protects his family home from the rising seas.. The Marshall Islands comprises of two chains of coral atolls, together with more than 1,000 islets. It is on average just two metres above sea level. The country faces an existential threat from rising sea levels with some predictions claiming that the islands will be swamped by the end of the 21st century. Majuro, Marshall Islands
 
¬© vlad sokhin / panos pictures

Ya disponible en el Repositorio Institucional de Recursos Abiertos - RUIdeRa de la uclm_es el TFG de andresfcv95 titulado "Inundaciones Hist√≥ricas en Daimiel (Ciudad Real, Castilla-La Mancha).
Pod√©is consultarlo en http://hdl.handle.net/10578/25361
.
El objetivo principal de este Trabajo Fin de Grado es conocer cu√°les han sido los episodios de inundaciones m√°s destacados en Daimiel y saber si tienen relaci√≥n entre ellos o un periodo de retorno espec√≠fico, y que los gestores del territorio tengan una base para poder actuar en el futuro para enfrentarse a estos acontecimientos. Del objetivo principal se derivan otros como; entender por qu√© cada cierto tiempo el casco urbano de Daimiel se inunda, cu√°les son las medidas que se han tomado y se deben tomar para mitigar los da√±os causados por estas avenidas de agua y las diferentes soluciones y medidas de mitigaci√≥n que se deben tomar frente a las futuras inundaciones que se pudieran producir. Por otro lado, tambi√©n se quiere interpretar los aspectos que est√°n √≠ntimamente relacionados con las avenidas de agua como la geomorfolog√≠a de los r√≠os y sus cuencas. El por qu√© se desbordan estos r√≠os cuando se producen importantes lluvias, por qu√© son r√≠os que en verano est√°n siempre secos y que en contadas ocasiones llevan agua. Estas y otras preguntas son a las que se intenta dar respuesta en este trabajo para entender mejor el funcionamiento de los r√≠os y c√≥mo es el entorno que nos rodea. Finalmente, se plantea cu√°l es el correcto uso y gesti√≥n que se debe hacer sobre las aguas superficiales, los r√≠os y sus respectivas llanuras de inundaci√≥n para en un futuro evitar da√±os materiales, econ√≥micos e incluso posibles p√©rdidas de vidas humanas
.
